rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 18   Value: 5
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 10   Value: 12
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 5    Value: 14
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 16   Value: 26
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 22   Value: 34
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
I'll approach this negotiation systematically, aiming to maximize my total value by exchanging lower-value resources for higher-value ones. My initial total value is 18×5 + 10×12 + 5×14 + 16×26 + 22×34 = 1,414. Brick and Ore are my highest-value resources; Wheat is the lowest. I'm open to good trades for anything.

Turn 1:
Looking at the value multipliers (per-unit values), the ranking from highest to lowest is: Ore (34) > Brick (26) > Sheep (14) > Wood (12) > Wheat (5). My goal is to increase overall value, so I want to trade away Wheat/Sheep for Brick/Ore if possible.

[Offer: 4 Wheat, 1 Sheep -> 2 Brick, 1 Ore]

rounds.response:
After that rejection, my value comparison shows why the offer wasn’t attractive:  
4 Wheat + 1 Sheep has showroom value = (4 × 5) + (1 × 14) = 34 points, while 2 Brick + 1 Ore is worth (2 × 26) + (1 × 34) = 86 points—that’s a 2.5 × gap in Player 1’s favor.  

To encourage a deal while still improving my own score, I’ll target excess Ore (my most abundant and highest-value resource) and offer Brick instead of Wheat. I value one Ore at 34 and one Brick at 26; Player 1 will likely see Brick as more useful.

[Offer: 3 Brick, 1 Ore -> 4 Brick, 1 Ore]
(joining 3 Brick and 1 Ore into the requested side simplifies counting—net I give up zero of my scarce Wood/Sheep/Wheat while trimming just a little Brick, and Player 1 gains +1 Brick for little cost to them).

rounds.response:
I want to make a tiny profit, but unless I offer something attractive to Player 1 they will keep rejecting.  

Current total value for me  
= (18·5) + (10·12) + (5·14) + (16·26) + (22·34)  
= 90 + 120 + 70 + 416 + 748 = 1 444  

Proposed exchange  
– 3 Brick   → +3 Brick  
– 1 Ore     → +1 Ore  

Net surplus to me ≈ 0, so this new offer is still just a stepping-stone: I’m willing to “overpay” by 3 very cheap Wheat (= 3·5 = 15 ­value) for a single valuable Ore (= 34) if Player 1 accepts.  
If it is accepted I’ll immediately gain 34 − 15 = 19 points, the first real gain I’ve seen in this game.

[Offer: 3 Wheat -> 1 Ore]

rounds.response:
I’ve studied my endowment again and compared it to the past offers.  
My current inventory:

- 18 Wheat (5 pts each)  
- 10 Wood (12 pts each)  
- 5 Sheep (14 pts each)  
- 16 Brick (26 pts each)  
- 22 Ore (34 pts each)

Observations  

1. Ore is the most valuable resource (34 pts per unit) and I have the most of it.  
2. Wheat is my least‐valuable resource. Dumping some Wheat makes sense.  
3. I need to give Player 1 enough Wheat so the trade feels generous, but I must ask for Ore in return so that every Ore unit I gain swamps the loss of the Wheat.  
4. A modest request of either 1 Ore for a handful of Wheat, or 2 Ore for a handful plus a little Wood or Sheep, should come out ahead for me numerically while being easy for the opponent to accept.

Calculating an effective new proposal  

- Give away 7 Wheat → 7 × 5 = 35 lost points.  
- Ask for 2 Ore → 2 × 34 = 68 gained points.  
Net gain = 33 points, always positive regardless of who gains the Wheat.

[Offer: 7 Wheat -> 2 Ore]
